Article.Abstract: BACKGROUND: The matrix protein of the influenza A virus and the matrix and capsid proteins of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) share striking structural similarities which may have evolutionary and biological significance. These similarities led us to hypothesize the existence of cross-reactivity between HLA-A2-restricted FLU-M1:58-66 and HIV-1 p17 GAG:77-85 epitopes. METHODS: The hypothesis that these two epitopes are cross-reactive was tested by determining the presence and extent of FLU/GAG immune cross-reactivity in lymphocytes from HIV-seropositive and seronegative HLA-A2+ donors by cytotoxicity assays and tetramer analyses. Moreover, the molecular basis for FLU/GAG cross-reactivity in HIV-seropositive and seronegative donors was studied by comparing lymphocyte-derived cDNA sequences corresponding to the TCR-beta variable regions, in order to determine whether stimulation of lymphocytes with either peptide results in the expansion of identical T-cell clonotypes. RESULTS: Here, we report evidence of cross-reactivity between FLU-M1:58-66 and HIV-1 p17 GAG:77-85 epitopes following in vitro stimulation of PBMC derived from either HIV-seropositive or seronegative HLA-A2+ donors as determined by cytotoxicity assays, tetramer analyses, and molecular clonotyping. CONCLUSION: These results suggest that immunity to the matrix protein of the influenza virus may drive a specific immune response to an HLA-A2-restricted HIV gag epitope in HIV-infected and uninfected donors vaccinated against influenza.
Article.ArticleTitle: Cross-reactivity between HLA-A2-restricted FLU-M1:58-66 and HIV p17 GAG:77-85 epitopes in HIV-infected and uninfected individuals.
Article.Affiliations: Department of Radiation Oncology, Medical University of South Carolina, Charleston, South Carolina 29425, USA. gattoni@radonc.musc.edu.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Cytotoxicity responses by lymphocytes from HIV seronegative donors. The patients PBMCs were mixed with T2 target cells presenting HLA-A2-restricted influenza A-derived FLU-M1:58-66. Cross-reactivity was assessed by testing the effector cells' ability to recognize the HIV.gag.77-85 as the antigen.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Environmental exposure to endemic/ubiquitous agent without evidence for disease

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Cytotoxicity responses by lymphocytes from HIV seronegative donors. The patients PBMCs were mixed with T2 target cells presenting HLA-A2-restricted influenza A-derived FLU-M1:58-66. The immunogenicity of the flu epitope was tested using the effector cells to lyse target cells loaded with flu-M1:58-66 as the antigen.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Environmental exposure to endemic/ubiquitous agent without evidence for disease

AssayInformation.AssayComments: PBMCs from HIV seropositive HLA-A2 donors were stimulated in-vitro FLUM1:58-66 then stained with FITC-labeled anti-CD8 mAb and HLA-A2/HIV.GAG:77-85 tetramer. Viable cells were analyzed by flow cytometry.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Environmental exposure to endemic/ubiquitous agent without evidence for disease

AssayInformation.AssayComments: PBMCs from HIV seropositive HLA-A2 donors were stimulated in-vitro FLUM1:58-66 then stained with FITC-labeled anti-CD8 mAb and HLA-A2/FLU-M1:58-66 tetramer. Viable cells were analyzed by flow cytometry.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Environmental exposure to endemic/ubiquitous agent without evidence for disease
Environmental exposure to endemic/ubiquitous agent without evidence for disease

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Cytotoxicity responses by lymphocytes from HIV seronegative donors. The patients PBMCs were mixed with T2 target cells presenting HLA-A2-restricted HIV-derived GAG:77-85. The immunogenicity of the flu epitope was tested using the effector cells to lyse target cells loaded with HIV.GAG:77-85 as the antigen.
PBMCs from HIV seropositive HLA-A2 donors were stimulated in-vitro HIV.GAG then stained with FITC-labeled anti-CD8 mAb and HLA-A2/FLU.58-66 tetramer. Viable cells were analyzed by flow cytometry.

Cytotoxicity responses by lymphocytes from HIV seronegative donors. The patients PBMCs were mixed with T2 target cells presenting HLA-A2-restricted HIV-derived GAG.77-85. Cross-reactivity was assessed by testing the effector cells' ability to recognize the Flu.MI:58-66 as the antigen.
PBMCs from HIV seropositive HLA-A2 donors were stimulated in-vitro HIV.GAG then stained with FITC-labeled anti-CD8 mAb and HLA-A2/HIV.GAG tetramer. Viable cells were analyzed by flow cytometry.
